texts.definition: Files that contain information to recreate game states.
markups: <style="Definition">Files that contain information to recreate game states.</style>

For various reasons, players may wish to take extended breaks from computer games and during this time turn off the computer. This causes a problem of how to recreate the game state at a later point in time which having <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> containing a game state can solve. A consequence of this is that players may return to that game state after failing instead of restarting a game, and this can in itself become a reason for creating <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> if the possibility exists. Likewise, if <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> are possible, players may create ones to have a freedom of testing things they would otherwise not test.
Wikipedia has an entry Saved Game that related to Save Files.

Most <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> provide support for <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style>, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%20series">Doom series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tomb%20Raider%20series">Tomb Raider series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mass%20Effect%20series">Mass Effect series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Europa%20Universalis%20series">Europa Universalis series</link></style>.

Supporting <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> in games consist creating the technical infrastructure that stores the game states and allows the game to take previously created <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> and load these game states into games. Handling them are typically support through <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>.

From considering players' experiences, creating <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> mainly consist of if they are created through <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style>, automatic saving, or all three. Care also needs to be taken supporting the <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> related to destroy and loading <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style>. <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> can be put on <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> to limit either the number of simultaneous files that can be used, making them into a form of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style> (and working against <style="Link"><link="save-scumming">Save Scumming</link></style> when the limit is one <style="CurrentLink">Save File</style>).

While there is typically a need or wish to have <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> store complete game states, these can sometimes be quite small due to gameplay being partitioned into <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> or other smaller units. A special case of this is when the only information that needs to be saved is how long players have progressed and in this case <style="Link"><link="password-save-files">Password Save Files</link></style> can be sufficient.

The presence of <style="Link"><link="unwinnable-game-states">Unwinnable Game States</link></style> can cause players to create <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> from which they will always lose <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, fail <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, or lose entire game instances.

When players know that they can return to stored game states, <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> can encourage them to engage in <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> with gameplay actions they would otherwise not do. More negatively, the possibility of creating <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> can lead to <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="save-scumming">Save Scumming</link></style>, which both lead to gameplay when intended <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> no longer work. While creating and loading <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> are <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> can give rise to additional <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20State%20Editing">Game State Editing</link></style>.

When the number of <style="CurrentLink">Save Files</style> are limited, i.e. when <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> are applied on them, they become <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that players need to consider for gameplay reasons.

<style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20State%20Editing">Game State Editing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="save-scumming">Save Scumming</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style>
<style="Link"><link="save-scumming">Save Scumming</link></style> when used together with <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style>
